articles.headline: State Lawmakers Defy Governors in a Covid-Era Battle for Power
articles.snippet: Legislators across the country, mostly Republicans, are moving to strip the powers of governors, many of them Democrats, who have taken on extraordinary authority to fight the pandemic.
articles.abstract: Legislators across the country, mostly Republicans, are moving to strip the powers of governors, many of them Democrats, who have taken on extraordinary authority to fight the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Partisan warfare over pandemic lockdowns and mask-wearing is on the wane in Washington: A bitter presidential election has been decided, coronavirus cases are plummeting nationally and vaccines are rolling out slowly but steadily.

articles.headline: ‘Like We’re Being Cursed’: First Covid and Now Waterlogged Homes
articles.snippet: Basics remain scarce in some parts of Texas, and many already battered by a year of the coronavirus now face a costly recovery.
articles.abstract: Basics remain scarce in some parts of Texas, and many already battered by a year of the coronavirus now face a costly recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Texas — After her pipes burst and flooded her house, after she spent one night on a church couch and another fleeing a four-alarm fire in the hotel where she and her husband sought refuge, Janet Culver, 88, finally made it home a week after Texas’ epic winter nightmare began.

articles.headline: Biden Changes P.P.P. Rules to Help the Self-Employed
articles.snippet: A more generous loan formula for solo ventures is meant to get more very small businesses into the Paycheck Protection Program. But bigger applicants face a two-week pause.
articles.abstract: A more generous loan formula for solo ventures is meant to get more very small businesses into the Paycheck Protection Program. But bigger applicants face a two-week pause.
articles.lead_paragraph: Aiming to put its own stamp on the Paycheck Protection Program, the Biden administration on Monday abruptly changed crucial program rules in ways intended to help the smallest and neediest companies, which have sometimes struggled to obtain aid from the federal relief effort.
articles.byline: By Stacy Cowley and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Garland, at Confirmation Hearing, Vows to Fight Domestic Extremism
articles.snippet: President Biden’s nominee for attorney general told the Senate Judiciary Committee that investigating the Capitol riot would be his first priority.
articles.abstract: President Biden’s nominee for attorney general told the Senate Judiciary Committee that investigating the Capitol riot would be his first priority.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Judge Merrick B. Garland, President Biden’s nominee for attorney general, said on Monday that the threat from domestic extremism was greater today than at the time of the Oklahoma City bombing in 1995, and he pledged that if confirmed he would make the federal investigation into the Capitol riot his first priority.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Engine Maker Under Scrutiny After Series of Aircraft Mishaps
articles.snippet: Regulators are investigating episodes involving Pratt & Whitney equipment that rained debris from planes and forced emergency landings.
articles.abstract: Regulators are investigating episodes involving Pratt & Whitney equipment that rained debris from planes and forced emergency landings.
articles.lead_paragraph: A recent series of startling airplane engine failures has cast a harsh light on Pratt & Whitney, the storied Connecticut aerospace manufacturer.
articles.byline: By Niraj Chokshi, Peter Eavis and David Gelles

articles.headline: As Pandemic Took Hold, Suicide Rose Among Japanese Women
articles.snippet: Job losses, urban isolation, household burdens: Covid-19 has compounded the pressures on women, raising alarms in a country that has worked to reduce some of the world’s highest suicide rates.
articles.abstract: Job losses, urban isolation, household burdens: Covid-19 has compounded the pressures on women, raising alarms in a country that has worked to reduce some of the world’s highest suicide rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Not long after Japan ramped up its fight against the coronavirus last spring, Nazuna Hashimoto started suffering panic attacks. The gym in Osaka where she worked as a personal trainer suspended operations, and her friends were staying home at the recommendation of the government.
articles.byline: By Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida

articles.headline: Trump’s Tax Returns Aren’t the Only Crucial Records Prosecutors Will Get
articles.snippet: For all that they reveal, tax returns have limitations. Other records from the former president’s accountants may help give a fuller picture of his finances.
articles.abstract: For all that they reveal, tax returns have limitations. Other records from the former president’s accountants may help give a fuller picture of his finances.
articles.lead_paragraph: When New York prosecutors finally get to examine the federal tax returns of former President Donald J. Trump, they will discover a veritable how-to guide for getting rich while losing millions of dollars and paying little to no income taxes.

articles.headline: For Women in Economics, the Hostility Is Out in the Open
articles.snippet: Studies have found that the field is plagued by a singular problem of gender bias. The latest evidence comes from the types of questions posed at seminars.
articles.abstract: Studies have found that the field is plagued by a singular problem of gender bias. The latest evidence comes from the types of questions posed at seminars.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few years ago, the economists Alicia Sasser Modestino and Justin Wolfers sat at the back of a professional conference and watched Rebecca Diamond, a rising star in their field, present her latest research on inequality. Or at least she was meant to present it — moments after she began her talk, the audience began peppering her with questions.

articles.headline: A Bristling Standoff Rattles Gun-Friendly Vermont
articles.snippet: In Pawlet, Vt., where a landowner opened a tactical weapons training site, a zoning dispute has escalated into something more dangerous.
articles.abstract: In Pawlet, Vt., where a landowner opened a tactical weapons training site, a zoning dispute has escalated into something more dangerous.
articles.lead_paragraph: PAWLET, Vt. — Fear has gradually spread in the town of Pawlet.

articles.headline: Future Vaccines Depend on Test Subjects in Short Supply: Monkeys
articles.snippet: The pandemic has highlighted the United States’ dependence on China for research animals, reviving calls for a “strategic monkey reserve.”
articles.abstract: The pandemic has highlighted the United States’ dependence on China for research animals, reviving calls for a “strategic monkey reserve.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Mark Lewis was desperate to find monkeys. Millions of human lives, all over the world, were at stake.
articles.byline: By Sui-Lee Wee and Bryan Tarnowski

articles.headline: Reading Between the Lines: A Conversation With Janet Yellen
articles.snippet: The Treasury secretary dropped hints about her priorities — if you know how to interpret them.
articles.abstract: The Treasury secretary dropped hints about her priorities — if you know how to interpret them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Janet L. Yellen, the Treasury secretary, has given only a handful of interviews since taking up her post about a month ago. Business leaders and investors hang on her every word, trying to divine how she and the Biden administration will steer policy and how this will affect the economy and the markets. Ms. Yellen, previously the chair of the Federal Reserve, is skilled at staying on message, but in an interview with me for the DealBook DC Policy Project, she hinted at some policy priorities in her typically understated way.

articles.headline: Stocks Rise as Fed Chair Says Light at the End of the Tunnel Remains Distant
articles.snippet: Jerome Powell’s Senate testimony allayed worries that signs of growth would lead the Fed to cut back on its support for the economy.
articles.abstract: Jerome Powell’s Senate testimony allayed worries that signs of growth would lead the Fed to cut back on its support for the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the better part of a year, stock investors have shrugged off the pandemic. Rising death tolls, rampant infections and widespread economic devastation haven’t interrupted the market’s rise for long.
